awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Game Theoretic Methods for Multiagent Coordination
awd_abstract_narration:
A multiagent system can be characterized by a collection of interacting subsystems each making local decisions in response to local information. There are numerous examples of multiagent systems spanning both the engineering and social sciences, e.g., wind farms, surveillance systems, and transportation networks. Regardless of the specific domain, the primary goal in such systems is to design admissible mechanisms for coordinating the behavior of the individual subsystems to ensure that the emergent collective behavior is desirable with respect to a system-level objective.  

Intellectual Merit
 
The overarching goal of this project is to develop game-theoretic methodologies for multiagent coordination with broad applicability to both social and engineering systems.  In the context of social multiagent systems, this project will focus on the derivation of optimal mechanisms for coordinating the collective behavior in situations where the society's sensitivity to such mechanisms is unknown, e.g., taxation mechanisms on traffic networks.  In the context of engineering multiagent systems, this project will focus on the derivation of (i) distributed control algorithms that guarantee that the multiagent systems exhibits the optimal correlated behavior and (ii) fundamental relationships pertaining to how informational patterns impact achievable performance guarantees in multiagent systems.

Broader Impacts

A central goal on this project involves promoting the general understanding of multiagent systems to the engineering community and beyond.  Undoubtedly, engineers will be responsible for the design of a wide array of multiagent systems with examples spanning all aspects of society. Successfully controlling such ?complex? systems requires that engineers be multi-disciplinary with a strong proficiency in both the engineering and social sciences. This project will seek to achieve this goal through direct interactions with K-12 students, public lectures, dissemination of course material at the intersection of social and engineering sciences, and direct interactions with industry to illustrate the applicability of the developed methodologies.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this proposal was to formally advance the role of game theory in multiagent coordination. This proposal sought to achieve this goal through an integrated research and education plan that built upon the PI's extensive preliminary work in the area of game theory and multiagent coordination. The key outcomes associated with this project are summarized below:

Influencing Social Behavior in Networked Systems: It is a well-known fact that uninfluenced social systems can exhibit highly inecient system behavior, e.g., transportation networks. Accordingly, the influence and coordination of social behavior is a fundamental challenge that engineers must account for. This project developed several mechanisms for improving the efficacy of societal behavior. A noteworthy result pertains to the derivation of taxation mechanims to optimize the price of anarchy in atomic congestion games. Here, the price of anarchy is a widely adopted metric that seek to measure the inefficiency of Nash equilbria in societal systems. 

Attaining Ecient Correlated Behavior Through Distributed Learning: There are many examples of distributed engineering systems where the desired global behavior exhibits a strong degree of correlation between the behavior of the individual subsystems. A well-known solution concept in game theory, termed (coarse) correlated equilibrium, eectively captures this notion of correlation. Unfortunately, there are no distributed learning algorithms in the existing literature that provide convergence to a specic (coarse) correlated equilibrium. This project resulting in the derivation of distributed learning algorithms that guarantee that the collective behavior will converge to the most ecient (coarse) correlated equilibrium.

Controlling Information: A New Paradigm in Multiagent Coordination: Information plays a fundamental role in the coordination of multiagent systems. The information available to the individual agents, either attained through communication or sensing, invariably influence their local decisions which in turn in influences the emergent global behavior. By allowing agents to communicate with one another, information transitions from being a hard constraint to a design choice. This project formally initiated a study on the role of information in multiagent coordination. In particular, this project lead to the derivation of (constrained) communication and control protocols that optimized the efficiency of the emergent collective behavior for important classes of multiagent systems. 

 


Last Modified: 12/23/2020
Modified by: Jason R Marden
por.por_txt_cntn:
The overarching goal of this proposal was  to formally advance the role of game theory in multiagent coordination.  This proposal sought to achieve this goal through an integrated research  and education plan that built upon the PI's extensive preliminary work  in the area of game theory and multiagent coordination. The key outcomes associated with this project are summarized below:

Influencing Social Behavior in Networked Systems: It  is a well-known fact that uninfluenced social systems can exhibit  highly inecient system behavior, e.g., transportation networks.  Accordingly, the influence and coordination of social behavior is a  fundamental challenge that engineers must account for. This project developed several mechanisms for improving the efficacy of societal behavior. A noteworthy result pertains to the derivation of taxation mechanims to optimize the price of anarchy in atomic congestion games. Here, the price of anarchy is a widely adopted metric that seek to measure the inefficiency of Nash equilbria in societal systems. 

Attaining Ecient Correlated Behavior Through Distributed Learning: There are many examples of distributed engineering systems where the  desired global behavior exhibits a strong degree of correlation between  the behavior of the individual subsystems. A well-known solution concept  in game theory, termed (coarse) correlated equilibrium, eectively  captures this notion of correlation. Unfortunately, there are no  distributed learning algorithms in the existing literature that provide  convergence to a specic (coarse) correlated equilibrium. This project resulting in the derivation of distributed learning  algorithms that guarantee that the collective behavior will converge to  the most ecient (coarse) correlated equilibrium.

Controlling Information: A New Paradigm in Multiagent Coordination: Information plays a fundamental role in the coordination of multiagent  systems. The information available to the individual agents, either  attained through communication or sensing, invariably influence their  local decisions which in turn in influences the emergent global  behavior. By allowing agents to communicate with one another,  information transitions from being a hard constraint to a design choice.  This project formally initiated a study on the role of information in multiagent coordination. In particular, this project lead to the derivation of (constrained) communication and control protocols that optimized the efficiency of the emergent collective behavior for important classes of multiagent systems.

					Submitted by: Jason R Marden
